This is currently almost impossible (at least not in a simple way).

What I suggest is to add a discriminator to `cascade`, so you can selectively add apply them to a subset of the pages.

```yaml
cascade:
  _forKinds: "**"
    _build:
      render: true
      list: always
      publishResources: false
```

/cc @username_1', 'title': 'Add cascade._forKinds', 'type': 'issue'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'regisphilibert', 'comment_id': 703776576.0, 'datetime': '2020-10-05 17:29:34+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': 'I did not know. Sections in my world often have their own `_index.md` from which I can manage `_build` but again... My world is limited.

Can I enquire how the `_forKind` selector works?

I will add a suggestion which might make you cringe depending on how far it is from your original design, but providing the `**` referenced in your example is indeed a glob syntax, why not:

1. Make cascade take slices of maps as well a map
2. Add a `_target` key to any slice so user can apply cascade using glob

ex:
```yaml
cascade:
  - _target: /california/*
     background: `yosemite.jpg`
  - _target: /california/sf/*
     background: `goldenbridge.jpg`
```

If this solves the problem at hand, it also adds more power to cascade without having to create too many `_index.md` down the tree...', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'bep', 'comment_id': 703780809.0, 'datetime': '2020-10-05 17:37:02+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': 'But we could probably do:

```
- _target: /california/*
```

Which would be the **content path**, and optionally:

```
- _target: {path: /california/*, kind: "**" }
```

Probably not valid YAML, but you get the drift.', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}
 {'action': 'created', 'author': 'regisphilibert', 'comment_id': 703781900.0, 'datetime': '2020-10-05 17:38:59+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_1', 'text': '```
- _target: {path: /california/*, kind: "**" }
```

Yes! Exciting, the more powerfull cascade, the more it could be pivotal when implementing #5074', 'title': None, 'type': 'comment'}

column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Add cascade._forKinds
username_0: A common request is to be able to turn off rendering of section pages for a given section, but not all of them. This is currently almost impossible (at least not in a simple way).

What I suggest is to add a discriminator to `cascade`, so you can selectively add apply them to a subset of the pages.

```yaml
cascade:
  _forKinds: "**"
    _build:
      render: true
      list: always
      publishResources: false
```

/cc @username_1
<issue_comment>username_1: I did not know. Sections in my world often have their own `_index.md` from which I can manage `_build` but again... My world is limited.

Can I enquire how the `_forKind` selector works?

I will add a suggestion which might make you cringe depending on how far it is from your original design, but providing the `**` referenced in your example is indeed a glob syntax, why not:

1. Make cascade take slices of maps as well a map
2. Add a `_target` key to any slice so user can apply cascade using glob

ex:
```yaml
cascade:
  - _target: /california/*
     background: `yosemite.jpg`
  - _target: /california/sf/*
     background: `goldenbridge.jpg`
```

If this solves the problem at hand, it also adds more power to cascade without having to create too many `_index.md` down the tree...
<issue_comment>username_0: Which doesn't solve _my particular_ problem (hitting just sections).
<issue_comment>username_1: `_target: /california/index.md` then.
<issue_comment>username_0: But we could probably do:

```
- _target: /california/*
```

Which would be the **content path**, and optionally:

```
- _target: {path: /california/*, kind: "**" }
```

Probably not valid YAML, but you get the drift.
<issue_comment>username_1: ```
- _target: {path: /california/*, kind: "**" }
```

Yes! Exciting, the more powerfull cascade, the more it could be pivotal when implementing #5074<issue_closed>

column5:
[{'action': 'opened', 'author': 'bep', 'comment_id': None, 'datetime': '2021-10-15 07:04:47+00:00', 'masked_author': 'username_0', 'text': "We have the `ignoreFiles` option, but it only works for a sub-set of Hugo's source files (content, data?), and changing it to mean something else would create havoc.

Long story short, what would be relatively simple to implement and pretty powerful is to add a `filter` option to the mount config, e.g.:

```toml
[module]
[[module.mounts]]
source = 'content'
target = 'content'
includeFiles = ['blog/**', 'docs/**']
excludeFiles = '**.jpg'
```

Some notes about the above:

* The include/exclude patterns are the regular Glob we use in other places; much faster than regexp and easier for people to reason about when it comes to file paths. They should contain Unix slashes even if on Windows.
* We accept either a string or a slice for these options.
* Since this needs to work on all file operations (dir listing, `.Stat`, `.Open`), we need to do this on the file system level.

/cc @regisphilibert @jmooring etc.", 'title': 'Add includeFiles and excludeFiles to mount configuration', 'type': 'issue'}]
column6:
<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Add includeFiles and excludeFiles to mount configuration
username_0: We have the `ignoreFiles` option, but it only works for a sub-set of Hugo's source files (content, data?), and changing it to mean something else would create havoc.

Long story short, what would be relatively simple to implement and pretty powerful is to add a `filter` option to the mount config, e.g.:

```toml
[module]
[[module.mounts]]
source = 'content'
target = 'content'
includeFiles = ['blog/**', 'docs/**']
excludeFiles = '**.jpg'
```

Some notes about the above:

* The include/exclude patterns are the regular Glob we use in other places; much faster than regexp and easier for people to reason about when it comes to file paths. They should contain Unix slashes even if on Windows.
* We accept either a string or a slice for these options.
* Since this needs to work on all file operations (dir listing, `.Stat`, `.Open`), we need to do this on the file system level.

/cc @regisphilibert @jmooring etc.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: [ERROR] Error: Cannot mix different versions of joi schemas when upgrading from 2.0.0-beta.14 to 2.0.0-beta.16
username_0: ### Have you read the Contributing Guidelines on issues?

- [X] I have read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://github.com/facebook/docusaurus/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#reporting-new-issues).

### Prerequisites

- [X] I'm using the latest version of Docusaurus.
- [X] I have tried the `npm run clear` or `yarn clear` command.
- [X] I have tried `rm -rf node_modules yarn.lock package-lock.json` and re-installing packages.
- [ ] I have tried creating a repro with https://new.docusaurus.io.
- [X] I have read the console error message carefully (if applicable).

### Description

After upgrading from version 2.0.0-beta.14 to 2.0.0-beta.16, [following this tutorial](https://docusaurus.io/docs/installation#updating-your-docusaurus-version)

we can´t run `npm start` anymore because it returns this error message:
```
[INFO] Starting the development server...
[ERROR] Error: Cannot mix different versions of joi schemas
npm ERR! code ELIFECYCLE
npm ERR! errno 1
npm ERR! site@0.0.0 start: `docusaurus start`
npm ERR! Exit status 1
npm ERR! 
npm ERR! Failed at the site@0.0.0 start script.
npm ERR! This is probably not a problem with npm. There is likely additional logging output above.

npm ERR! A complete log of this run can be found in:
npm ERR!     C:\Users\paulo\AppData\Roaming\npm-cache\_logs\2022-02-28T13_50_37_511Z-debug.log

```

I have tried the following with no success:
 - Reverted all changes and executed the process again
 - Following the steps [described here](https://github.com/easyops-cn/docusaurus-search-local/issues/31)
 - Manually deleted package-lock.json and ran `npm install` again
 - [Changing manually the version on package-lock.json](https://github.com/redpanda-data/documentation/commit/8e1bf6dc0d8b2fc2e4e717d8f97f880714299760)


Here's the detailed log message:

```

- Docusaurus version used:  2.0.0-beta.16
- Environment name and version (e.g. Chrome 89, Node.js 16.4): 
- Operating system and version (e.g. Ubuntu 20.04.2 LTS): Windows 10 Version	10.0.19043 Build 19043



### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to fix this bug myself.
<issue_comment>username_1: Still waiting for the OP to give me permissions, since this is a private repo. We are in touch on Discord.
<issue_comment>username_2: I'd suggest trying to delete the `package-lock.json` file and reinstall

If this doesn't work, run `npm why joi` and paste the output there
<issue_comment>username_0: @username_1 looks like the NPM/node version was indeed the culprit here. 
Upgrading them and forcing the values on package.json solved the issue.

Here's how my package.json looks like now

```json
{
  "name": "site",
  "version": "0.0.0",
  "private": true,
  "scripts": {
    "docusaurus": "docusaurus",
    "start": "docusaurus start",
    "build": "docusaurus build",
    "swizzle": "docusaurus swizzle",
    "deploy": "docusaurus deploy",
    "clear": "docusaurus clear",
    "serve": "docusaurus serve",
    "write-translations": "docusaurus write-translations",
    "write-heading-ids": "docusaurus write-heading-ids"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@docusaurus/core": "2.0.0-beta.16",
    "@docusaurus/preset-classic": "2.0.0-beta.16",
    "@easyops-cn/docusaurus-search-local": "^0.21.4",
    "@mdx-js/react": "^1.6.21",
    "@svgr/webpack": "^6.2.0",
    "clsx": "^1.1.1",
    "file-loader": "^6.2.0",
    "prism-react-renderer": "^1.2.1",
    "raw-loader": "^4.0.2",
    "react": "^17.0.1",
    "react-dom": "^17.0.1",
    "url-loader": "^4.1.1"
  },
  "engines": {
    "node": ">=16.13.2",
    "npm": ">=8.3.1"
  },
  "browserslist": {
    "production": [
      ">0.5%",
      "not dead",
      "not op_mini all"
    ],
    "development": [
      "last 1 chrome version",
      "last 1 firefox version",
      "last 1 safari version"
    ]
  }
}<issue_closed>
<issue_comment>username_1: Great to know it's solved! If you don't have further queries, feel free to remove me from the organization

<issue_comment>username_1: @username_0 I'm confused where eligibility is coming from other than as a default prop or mocked in a unit test - is the API passing this back to us?
<issue_comment>username_0: Yes @camerontesterman created this for us in the API.
<issue_comment>username_0: Cool, I just pushed an update.

<issue_start><issue_comment>Title: Nodejs.org down
username_0: I noticed this as our Travis CI builds keep failing since a few minutes.

Location: Germany


This page (https://nodejs.org/en/) is currently offline. However, because the site uses Cloudflare's Always Online™ technology you can continue to surf a snapshot of the site. We will keep checking in the background and, as soon as the site comes back, you will automatically be served the live version. Always Online™ is powered by Cloudflare \| Hide this Alert
<issue_comment>username_1: I just checked and it's not down for me. Would you be able to try again using another device?
<issue_comment>username_2: I'm seeing downloads from nodejs.org also fail with 522 errors
<issue_comment>username_0: Maybe dedicated to Cloudflare: https://www.cloudflarestatus.com/incidents/hptvkprkvp23
<issue_comment>username_3: Anyone still seeing any issues? Looks like the Cloudflare incident is resolved now on their end.

/cc @nodejs/build for visibility<issue_closed>
